description.text: A mount to use rollerblade wheels on an aluminium Suitcase. Not yet printed/tested.

This is a no-screw fixation system to quickly attach/detach a laser module to a nema17 motor (on the extruder) to convert your 3D printer in a laser CNC. No holes for screws have been added due to the different laser modules out there. Just edit the freecad sources or drill it yourself to fit your laser module.

I made this because I wanted to have a modular laser system to fit on my extruder, so I can change the laser module easily or remove the entire system without messing with any screw.

I also use it to fix the cable chain as you can see. A BIG cable chain 'cause I have lots of wires to the extruder, so I ended using several network FTP cables into the chain.
Tolerances taken into account. Remember to add support to the external pin. Recommended ABS print. Build Images are printed in carbon fibre embedded material and ABS.

Rough and low-poly take on the plasma grenades found in the Fallout world. I'm quite pleased with how it came out with the amount of time I spend on it.

I'd really love to see this printed and painted, I've also left the case hollow so you can use it for storage or for electrical components if you chose it to light up.

I've also included the 3D Studio Max file in case some of the parts are a bit of a close fit.

For the case and both end caps you can use whatever colour plastic you want, that goes for the paint scheme as well. I'd recommend printing the bottom and top rings with transparent plastic, if you chose to place electrics and LED's to make it glow. If you don't have transparent material, you can just print them and paint them as well.

description.text: CUSTOMIZED SPOOL HOLDER FOR PRUSIA I3. COULD BE USED FOR OTHER APPLICATIONS AS WELL.
DESIGNED WITH GOOGLE SKETCHUP.
A parametric soap dish with a wall mount, designed in Rhino grasshopper + 3ds Max using a voronoi algorithm.

Oddly enough, ABS prints turn out better than PLA, unlesse you use serious cooling so that no shards will curl upward.
You will have to use support for the whole main part.
An acetone or MEK finish is higly recommended!

author: ncapaldi1985

title: Bulge Head: a strangely round volume.

description.text:
This model shows the volume above the xy-plane, outside of a unit sphere and inside the cardioid of revolution Rho=1+Cos(Phi) (in spherical coordinates). A classic Multivariable Calculus problem asks you to find the volume of the solid. (Of course, using spherical coordinates is the easiest way to solve the problem.)

Equivalently, the region in the xy-plane above the y-axis, outside the unit circle, and inside the cardioid r=1+Cos(Theta) (in polar coordinates) is revolved around the y-axis, creating the "bulge head" volume of revolution.

This object was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Ryan McDonnell ('17). You can find more details about this model here: http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/21/bulge-head-solid/

This object was printed on a FormLabs Form 1+ printer using the clear resin. We used 0.2mm slices. It took 190mL resin! The print came out really well. There is just a tiny bit of a bulge at the bottom where the majority of the supports were placed.

The .form file used to print the object is included.

description.text: This is a rotating cube puzzle based off of an old design I had made when I was in the 6th Grade using snap counting cubes. Years later, my library got a 3D printer, and I decided to build a cube puzzle like the ones I made in the 6th Grade. At the end of the photo album are pictures of the designs that can be made by rotating different parts of the cube. More pieces for different puzzles may be added at a later date.

The name and orientation of the part is noted in the diagrams provided. The arrows point in the direction of the connector, so that the connector will go into the hole of the part it is attached to. All parts should be labeled. It should be noted that this was designed from the top layer downwards, so the piece connecting the top layer will have a piece with a connector to be placed into a hole on the middle layer(T1 in this case), and that a piece in the middle layer has a connector to be placed in a hole in the bottom layer (M1 into B1). Also, expand the pictures to see the labels.

comments.text: This.. is beautiful. The idea of a twisty puzzle where each part is connected in a similar fashion to this is what inspired by Quasar Puzzle, which I made last year in 7th grade and recently uploaded to Thingiverse. This is like a higher-order version of that, so it's pretty awesome. Good Job!

description.text:
This is a mini-makerbot for your cube farm:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8012 It just wouldn't be the same without your epic 3D Printer, now would it? ADDED:
Makerbot_V2.stl - Just a few tweaks.
Makerbot_WKeyring.stl - Added a small hole in the top corner, so it can be put on a keychain. Untested currently. ADDED 6/17/2011:
Makerbot_v3.stl - Made outside columns thicker. Moved keyring hole to bottom, for a bigger and stronger keyring. ADDED 6/18/2011:
Makerbot_v4.stl - Added Fan holes. Very slightly thicker nozzle.
FileCabinet.stl - Simple 3 drawer file cabinet, by request. ADDED 6/19/2011:
Makerbot_v5.stl - Added small hole in top for mini-filament. (extrude a little bit of plastic, cut off, glue in mini-hole on top)
-Picture of white v5 with green mini-filament added. ADDED 6/21/2011:
Makerbotv6.stl - Deeper hole for mini-filament. Mini-USB detail added.
Base(3,4,6).stl - Base for legs
Leg.stl - Legs -Base and Legs added, make your mini-Makerbot into a mini robot, ready to replicate and conquer!* Or use it to display something else. *Note that this will not actually happen...Hopefully.

Print.
Reversal is greatly suggested. Because it is awesome. (Also Cool -> Slowdown would be a good idea (I used 20sec for min time)) ADDED:
Found it prints a bit better when build platform temp is lower than normal, around ~100 *C.

description.text:
I make comes from two ideas: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:278078 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52810. Make a propeller to fly is not an easy task as well with a propeller that has been proven to fly and have a fairly light weight and combine everything. So I thank them, nglasson and Landru.

To get the fly fairly straight up takes a few time the exercise before finally created the video, I do not know how the altitude may be more than 3 meters (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rzncnjJ12FM).

Usage advice, hold the holder of approximately 2/3 of the bottom using the thumb and forefinger of your left hand, upper air flow is down and the propeller rotated clockwise. Rotate several times using the right hand index finger clockwise to a position slightly to the middle of the propeller. It should play in the wider space, not in the room for very thin blades would break if hit a wall or something.

I print them using PLA, with the layer height 0,2mm, also with a brim 2 mm, support is not needed. If the holes are still covered, use a drill for drilling holes 0.8 mm in diameter.

Remove brim using scissors, then sandpaper brim remaining (size: 80 and 320). Sandpaper (size: 80, 320 and 1000) all surfaces in contact, ie at the propeller with the holder, the holder with a paper clip hook. I attach sandpaper to ice cream stick with using double-sided tape, such as the photo attachment.

To balance the blades, insert the needle into the hole in the propeller, then turn let it stop and do this a couple of times, marked with a permanent marker lightest part is the tip of the blades that are the top than the other end. Then sandpaper parts that are not marked, remove dust, play a few times, then check if it is balanced, if not, do it again this process until you get a balanced propeller.

Cut the paper clip along the 30mm and straighten using pliers, bend the letters u 5 mm formed at one end with a width of approximately 1.5 mm, insert it into the hole propeller. Then create a hook with the help of screws size 4 mm. Do the same thing on the other propeller.

Attach 2 pieces of rubber bands corresponding to the width of the hook, not too tight or too loose, diameter approximately 45 mm.

title: Athena Bust (Greek Statue 3D Scan)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D scan of an Athena bust from the Altes Museum in Berlin.

I found the file here: http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Athenea-Altes-Museum-Berlin/4186336

I used MeshMixer to edit the file and make it 3D printable, it took some work but the result is nice. I deleted noise objects, filled holes, modeled areas with different brushes, plane cut a flat base, oriented it upright and scaled it 125 mm in height.

http://www.3dwp.nl

description.text:
This program is a simple and fast text displayer. Inside you find a handmade font, that gives the option to be resized to any size you want and to any depth/height you want.
I tried to create a font that has a minimum of polygons but still is good readable.
The only problem is that Openscad can't handle strings, so text have to be placed letter by letter. I used this polygon generator program (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9290) to create the letters very quickly.

Place the .SCAD file in your working directory. In your Openscad document type: use #text.scad# (replace # with < and > )
text("a", 10, 5); Where the first parameter is the text (between quotes);
The second parameter is the size of the letter;
The third parameter is the depth/height of the letter. Or simply open the text.scad file and run it.

author: steveneng

title: Rogowski coil current probe, FreeCAD parametrized

description.text:
A Rogowski coil is used to measure the current in a wire through the center of the coil. See for details for example:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rogowski_coil

The FreeCad script generates the body of a Rogowski coil with specified dimensions and windings etc. The gap in of the coil makes it possible to easily slide the coil over a current carrying wire (shown in gray on the first figure in the gallery)..

The windings on the coil are guided by small channels and there are two holes in the body of the coil to feed the incoming and outgoing leads. The wire at the end of the coil can be guided back to the beginning using the channel in the middle of the ring.

An alternative design for a Rogowski coil can be found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:283430

The design in the attached file: rigowki.stl was made with the attached FreeCAD script. In the script parameters such as inner and outer radius and height and the number of windings can be modified.

The shown Rogowski coil was made on a XYZ da Vinci jr with 0.2mm layer thickness sliced with XYZware with the settings as shown in the figure.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0UaACqWH4q9

I got a really nice, accurate airsoft replica of WE Luger P08, but this classic piece of German Engineering doesn't really have a picantinny rail system available for it. Until now! This attachment will give your Luger a top and side rail that should fit most picantinny-compatible sights, lights, lasers, and grips!

Please keep in mind this model was built with powder or resin-based printers in mind. This should print on extrusion-based printers but it might take a long time and will likely require a decent amount of support structure.  
I haven't personally had this printed yet but I will update this once I do. However if you do print this yourself you should be able to simply replace the trigger plate with this piece and be good to go!

description.text:
This can be slid over the home button of an iphone. It helps prevent children from accidentally exiting movies and games while playing with the phone.
It can then be slid on the back of the phone when not is use.  In this position it provides full access to the home button.
This was sized to fit an iphone 4 in a thin Incase shell.  It does fit an iphone with no case, but slides off easily because of the glass surface.  I have not tested it's fit on any other case. You may need to modify before printing for another case.

I suggest you print the item using these settings. They will insure the item is filled 100%. http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2011/03/18/super-sweet-printing-tech-zero-extra-shells/ The print includes small mouse ears on the corners to prevent pealing and warping when printing raftless. Just cut them off when done. If printing with a raft you can remove these from the source before printing.

This is a check valve designed for a 3/8" hose. I use two of them in combination with a squeeze bulb to move water (from the boat bilge to a bucket).

I printed the parts using ABS and fine settings on CURA. The small, conical shaped plunger is inserted in the part with exterior threads. The point of the cone goes toward the small opening. The channels on the edge of the cone ride on ridges of the exterior-threaded piece. I use an acetone dampened cloth to wipe the end of the cone and the mating surface inside of the small piece with the exterior threads to polish them. These two surfaces provide the seal to ensure one-way flow.
With the cone inserted on the exterior-theaded piece, screw on the outer piece (with the arrow) over the piece with the exterior threads. Be sure to keep the arrow pointed up and the cone pointed down as you screw the two pieces together so that the plunger stays in the bottom fo the smaller piece.
Water will only flow one way, in the direction of the arrow (away from the point of the inner cone).

title: Ormerod 2 Y-idler with Rod twist fix and belt tensioning

description.text:
I have modified fotomases mod for Twisted rod to include a Belt tensioning and stronger construction becouse i had problems with it Cracking at the M6 countersunk scews.

You will need 2xM4x20mm Bolts and 4xM4Nuts for belt tensioning and Rod Twist correction.
1xM3x30 bolt and 1xM3 Nut for the belt tension bracket.

For the bearing the same M3 bolt from Original Idler should work fine.

comments.text: I cannot see how this can be used to adjust the height of the y rod.
comments.author: GroundAttack

comments.text: It does work to a small degree ,Works by untightening the 2 bolts that hold the Y Endplate and Idler together then i usualy push down the idler so you get the lowest position and adjust the M4 till its abaut level. It never completely removed my rod twist but it got it to a reasonable tolerance. Fotomas will know more. I just modified his idler(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:646198) to have belt tensioning and stronger end so it would not crack so fast.
comments.author: GroundAttack

Print.

This is a whole Scrabble set I designed and made to be used for replacement pieces or to build your own set from scratch...

Here's a video explaining how to set the pieces up for dual extrusion and explains the difference between my three different designs...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AxjSmcHZi48&feature=youtu.be

The dimensions are 19x19x4 which is the standard scrabble piece size...

I have 1 design for dual extrusion which takes to STLs... "Dual_Letter_X" and "Dual_Shell_X"... I explain in the video how to print them if you're not familiar with dual extrusion...

I also have two designs for single extrusion... One with a cut in where the letter is and another with extruded letters so you can make a Z stop at 4mm and change filament to a different color...

Everything else is self explanatory.... If you have an questions or comments, feel free to leave a comment or message me directly...

Enjoy!!!

Watch the video.... Also, here is an Instructables...

http://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Print-your-own-Scrabble-Set/

title: Alien Fetus Fridge Magnet Baby - Low Poly

description.text:
This was made from a CT scan of a full term human fetus from an 80+ year old collection, original size, and polygon reduced to low resolution. This specimen was highly desiccated and looks freakishly like an alien baby! I printed and mounted two magnets, making it a great fridge magnet, and a wonderful conversation piece.

I have several printed fetal specimens over at https://www.etsy.com/shop/FetalReproductions?ref=hdr_shop_menu, including a high-resolution version of this baby and several other awesome fetal fridge magnets, so check those out, and keep checking, I'm adding several prints a week both here and on etsy!
CT Scan, Cleaned of erroneous material, and polygon reduced using Meshlab.

comments.text: Hi Gongjiaji,  to make sure the details came out on these, I had to print them quite slowly (~20-25mm/s) and make sure the extruded with was not too high (<0.44mm).  My printer has a 0.35mm extruder, but if you have a 0.50mm you may not be able to achieve your desired level of detail.  I printed many extra parts trying to tweak the printer settings and model, so you may have to try a couple of test runs.

title: Puff and sip mouse for people suffering from paraplegia

description.text:
Rob Edwards and I built this puff and sip mouse for a person that had no use of his limbs to be able to control a computer mouse.

Here is a link to the Arduino code: https://github.com/robertcedwards/Alex-Mouse

We used an Arduino Yun for wireless updating since the person we built this for lived in a different state. You could use a normal Uno (Will fit in the case above) or another type of Arduino like a Arduino Pro Mini, but you may want to mod the case or at least use hot glue to attach it to the case.

For the mouth piece we used a piece of food grade silicone. I think we used 3/8 ID tubing, but can't be for sure. The OD of the piece is 11.2mm.

Joystick: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9032
Joystick Breakout: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9110
Barometer: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12039
USB Keyboard mouse tutorial: https://www.sparkfun.com/tutorials/337

description.text: Designed by Jack McCandless

I always have need for a good/better vertex to construct space frames.
This derivative thing just makes a few 'improvements' to the original design.
First of all, I've modularized the code somewhat.  This doesn't make any particular improvement, but it will make it easier to see what's going on, and how to add to it in the future when more vertices are needed.
Second, being the slave to phi (1.618) that I am, I changed things like the thickness of the connector to be proportional to the radius of the rods that you're using (instead of a fixed value).
I've also made a change such that the length of the connector is automatically calculated proportional to the length of the rods that you're using.  The base size is 10mm, and it grows by an appropriately 'phi' influenced length.  So, the ones for a 36" rod, for example, are closer to about 20mm, rather than 10mm.
With these changes, it becomes rather trivial to make good new connectors for any size, by just changing the single diameter value, and the rod length.
I've played with a lot of vertex designs over the past few months.  This is one of the most compact, and easy to utilize.  I give props to Sjoerd de Jong for the simplicity of the design.
In the picture, the struts are 36" long.  The overall height of the structure is about 8'.  With this design, the fit is strong enough that you can actually assemble the thing with one person.  If you've ever done dome development, you might recognize this is a 'good thing'.

1) Download the .scad file, and choose which vertex type you want to construct.
2) Put in the appropriate rod radius (in millimeters)
3) Print out enough vertices to achieve the job
4) Slip rods into the appropriate places
5) Rejoice!

description.text: This is an electromagnet demispool, half of the hollow spool for a two inch nail electromagnet.

After making the first demispool, check to see that a two inch by one eighth inch diameter common nail fits snugly.  If it doesn't, change the dimensions of the demispool hole or alter the skeinforge parameters until you make a snug fitting demispool.  Once you've made one snug fitting demispool, make another, and fit the nail through both.  Then put wire, preferably fine magnet wire, through the perforations for support, then wind it around the spool to make an electromagnet.  Afterwards, the end of the wire can be fitted through the perforations to keep the winding tight.
The base and top demispools are identical, in the picture the base demispool is colored yellow and the top demispool is colored white to distinguish them.  The nail is colored blue light grey.  The perforations are to provide support for the wire ends and to provide mounting holes to attach the electromagnet to something else.
Besides wrapping the electromagnet by hand, you could also use an electric screwdriver or drill operated on low voltage to turn a one eighth inch drill fitted through the spools.  If you the one eighth inch drill is not long enough, you could try a nail with its head cut off so it could fit in the drill chuck, fitted partially through the spools.  If neither is long enough, you could cut a one eighth inch pipe, usually available in hobby stores, to length with a small pipe cutter.
The demispool is one inch (25.4 mm) high, half the length of the shaft of a two inch nail.  The center hole is one eight of an inch (3.175 mm) in diameter, the diameter of a common two inch nail.  The base is 1.2 mm thick, three standard (0.4 mm thick) layers high.  The wall thickness of the spool is 2 mm.  The perforations are two mm in diameter and they are three mm from the octogon corners.  The inner radius of the octogon is 10 mm, the outer radius is 10.82 mm and the sides are 8.28 mm long.
To quickly alter the dimensions of the demispool center hole so that it will make a snug fit you can scale the spool xy, as a side effect this will change the perforation diameter and octogon size.  To alter the height of the demispool, you can the scale the spool in the z direction, as a side effect this will change the height of the base.
To change a dimension without side effects, the Art of Illusion file with all the intermediate shapes is included.  To change the center hole diameter, change the radius of the nail hole, then subtract the nail hole from the perforated spool to make a new electromagnet demispool.  Then convert electromagnet demispool to a triangle mesh, and simplify the triangle mesh.  Then select the electromagnet demispool and export it as electromagnet_demispool.stl.  To change other dimensions, the entire constuction sequence is the following.  Make an octogon polygon then convert it to a mesh, called octogon mesh, extrude that to make the extruded octogon.  Subtract the spool negative inner cylinder from the spool negative outer box to make the spool negative hollow cylinder.  Subtract the spool negative hollow cylinder from the extruded octogon to make the filled spool.  Make perforations 0 though 7, then join them with the join objects script to make the perforations.  Subtract the perforations from the filled spool to make the perforated spool.  Then subtract the nail hole from the perforated spool to make the electromagnet demispool.  After each boolean operation, convert the shape to a triangle mesh, then simplify that mesh by choosing Edit Objects, then choosing Simplify Mesh, to be on the safe side you can then click Optomize Mesh.
This part was made with Tinkercad. Edit the part online at: https://tinkercad.com/p/acc0591e6a365471

title: K-12 Skill Builder Lesson Plan - Tinkercad Navigation Race [Revised 11/28]

description.text:
**Revised 11/28/15 - new materials linked below. Choose revision 1 materials if you want a shorter activity (12 - 18 minutes), revision 2 materials for prolonged practice (18 - 24 minutes).

Introduction

Ever introduced your class to new software in the hopes that they could use it to complete a project, only to realize that many of your students are getting hung up on the minutiae of the software? Students need time to practice! But projects ask them to dive right in; often, the first time they're introduced to a new tool or technique, they're only apply it once or twice, which often misses the opportunity to reinforce and encourage a kind of fluency that can be transfer and become a tool at the ready when working creatively.

This is the first in what will be a series of lessons that target a very specific skill. It gets students practicing that skill for an extended period of time while - hopefully - having fun and feeling a sense of accomplishment while doing so. My hope is that we as a community of educators can create more and more of these kinds of skill builders; and share them with each other so that we can all benefit from each others' experimentation in the classroom (and iterate to improve)! While this lesson applies only to Tinkercad, I'd be pumped if more educators developed and shared lessons like these for other modeling software packages.

Lesson

Learning Objective: Students will be able to navigate efficiently in TinkerCAD.

Essential Questions: Why are the tools of navigation so important in a 3D modeling environment?
How can we be sure that an object is where we want it to be?

Modeling software: Tinkercad

Level: Beginner (this is a great "first days" lesson with Tinkercad)

Requisite Skills & Understandings: A Tinkercad account for each student.
The ability to navigate (orbit, pan, zoom), place and resize primitives, use the workplane and ruler, make a hole, group, and subtract one primitive from another.

Pedagogical Suggestions: have students work in pairs

Common Core Standards: to be updated

Preparation & Guidance:
Before the lesson:

  • Electronically distribute the Google Doc (linked below) with the the instructions and space to complete the before the lesson. Ideas around how to create electronic copies while being able to track and review their work are also below. (For this lesson to work well, you'll want to establish structures around using Google Documents, Google Drive, and taking screenshots earlier in the semester.)
  • Try the lesson out before the students do.
  • Check links within the document to be sure that none of them are broken.

The Do Now that I developed for this lesson highlights one reason for the importance of navigation. To develop a context for that conveys its importance:

  • The Do Now shows a sequence of images, each one allowing the viewer to better determine how well aligned four letters are.
  • With each image, ask, "Are the letters where you thought they were?" Followup: "Why weren't you able to tell before? Why are you able to tell now?"
  • If the word perspective does not come up naturally, insert it somewhere within the discussion (one way to get it to come up from the Do Now is to ask: "What changed with each picture?")
  • Once "perspective" becomes an operating keyword within the lesson, ask: "How can you change your perspective?"
  • Ideally, as students answer, the ideas of getting closer (zoom), moving around (orbit), and moving left and right or up and down (pan) will come up. These are keywords and should make their way onto the board and into student notes.

The activity is supposed to feel a little competitive. If this works for your students, play it up as such.

Resources: (please copy and adapt at will)

  • Tinkercad file: access here. After logging into your Tinkercad account, click "Copy & Tinker".
  • Tinkercad file Revision 2 - More challenge! More things to find! More practice time! [access here]https://tinkercad.com/things/4DXM8rSErXv)
  • Handout: Google Doc with step-by-step instructions
  • Handout for Revision 2 - Google Doc with step-by-step instructions and space for students to confirm their progress - please copy
  • Paper handout - I provide one to each group so that they know what they're looking for
  • Presentation: Prezi with lesson structure and Do Now
    • Note: This is a dynamic worksheet that students complete to "win the race" (ie. verify they've done it). It also contains end-of-activity reflection questions. This can be distributed electronically to your students - Google Classroom and Doctopus both offer free ways of being able to do so while also being able to monitor progress, provide feedback, and grade their work.

Differentiation: to be developed
Nothing to print here! This is an activity that gets students working on their navigation skills!

author: RadiantDragoon87

description.text:
You can use waterproof epoxy to glue together the pieces. The pieces are interchangeable. There are different models for cargo and military vessels. At the moment, there are no propulsion methods. I'm working on motor integration, propellers or some alternate method of propulsion. You may need to re-size and add support structures. This work is still in progress, so stability issues, propulsion issues and potential other problems are still, unfortunately, present. Currently, I am working on finding a way to keep the boat stable, without requiring too many non-3d printed parts. If you find any issues that i haven't mentioned, please comment them below, and I will try to get around to fixing them. The you would be pretty much my favorite person ever if you actually fixed them and sent me them so I can include them in my next update(you will be credited for making the part). If you make parts PLEASE LINK THEM! I will include them in my next update and credit you. Hell, you can even put your name on the part. But seriously, make parts! To edit the STL's, you have to use a CAD program. Linked below are two free ones. Blender: http://www.blender.org/
SketchUp: http://www.sketchup.com/ Use the blank model for new peices! Happy Printing =)

I like 3d drawings, I like printing these drawings.  I also like boats, and interchangeable models.  That's it really.  The Battleship and Cargo ship models are inspired by their respective real world counterparts.  
I made the models in Sketchup and touched them up using Blender.  Again, feel free to modify and upload these files on this site or other sites.

Customized nose cone for the printable rocket.
See also the original Drabbit: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7510
Made with http://meshmixer.com and the ears from the Stanford Bunny http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3731 and Dragon Head http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1462
Printable, multipart, snap together rockets have some pretty awesome customization and mashup potential!

Pop off your boring old nose cone and slap this bad boy on. Warning: I Am Not A Rocket Scientist, probably not the most aerodynamic modification.
It's 116mm tall, so if you are using an ABP, you might have to cut it up into 2 parts and glue it together... don't just resize it or it won't fit on the rest of the rocket (unless you resize the whole rocket).

comments.text: Woops - I think I miss read this and thought you meant to split an STL object in half. To split a bed of several parts which is one STL, like raspberry_mount_3.stl etc in Cura you add it to your print area, right click on the object (probably grey as it's too big to fit) and choose "Split object into parts". This will split all objects in the STL to be managed so you can then move them around, rotate etc.

comments.text: Slic3r has the option(s) to split STL's on the print bed as it creates the slicing Gcode. Check out Josef Prusa's video which includes slicing objects in half etc... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uvV6z2ogTs

title: Improved FolgerTech Kossel Bottom Corner (Motor Mount)

description.text:
The 'stock' ones were too thick for the t-nuts to clamp the extrusions well, even when cranked so tight that the plastic started to crack. (You could move most of them by hand!)
They were also PLA, and they melted with the heat of the motors. (See the pic with the black part)

I simply thinned the area where the t-nuts mount to give more room for them to clamp, plus I printed my new parts in ABS so they would be more resilient to heat.

When assembling, I also used longer screws to mount the motors, with washers on the heads and cork gaskets on the stepper motors. (This provides insulation from a warm motor, and reduces noise too)

*** Some may say I was running my motors at too high of a current, and that may be, but they were skipping at any lower setting. The pulleys that were provided were 36T so they required more torque. When I switched to my new corners that I printed, I also changed to 20T pulleys and lowered the current until the motors did not slip with the 20T pulleys. This also gave me finer resolution. (Note that I was using 29T 'GeeTech' pulleys after installing my new corners, but found my prints were skewed quite a bit and found the 29T pulley teeth did not mesh well with GT2 belt. So I ordered some 20T pulleys and my prints are AWESOME now!)

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Spool holder for 6mm frame

description.text:
Clamp style holder for 1/8th aluminum or steel frames. Uses 1/4" aluminum rod for the extension. 8mm rod for the spool rod.

4mm screws and nuts to clamp together.

I made this initially to spin part: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:543083 around on a pivot. I decided to spend a little more time with this design & make it parametric. The included STL file is sized for the 64 tetrahedron shape listed above.

You can either edit the openscad file or open this in the thingiverse customizer to make the size you want.

Limitations
In the current version it will not size correctly if you go below 24mm for the Inside Width Clearance Distance or below 54mm for the Gimbal distance. I will take a look at fixing that soon.
